[soft] I never left. [sighs]
[confused] But, um, why didn't you ever, [breaking], show yourself again, I mean, through all those years of struggling, you know, raising my children alone after Harold died?
[regretful] Well, um, the rules of our magic are, [careful], strict about interference, and, you know, you needed to find your own strength, I mean, without relying on wishes.
Um, well, I'm dying. [laughs bitterly]
[pained] That's why I'm here now, because the, [heavy], rules change when a life approaches its, [whispered], natural end. [pauses]
So after seventy years of, [bitter], silence, you appear at my deathbed with, [sarcastic], what exactly—some magical cure that comes with, [exhausted], another set of your precious rules?
No cure, dear one, but a, [tender], final wish before I must pass my duties to another lost child.

[stunned] Well, um, I spent so many nights, [nostalgic], dreaming of what I'd wish for if you ever, [yearning], came back, but now, I mean, sitting here with these old bones, [tired], everything I wanted seems so pointless.

[defeated] She won't come.

[mysterious] Well, um, she's already on her way here, because, [gentle], sometimes fairy godmothers plant seeds of, [hopeful], forgiveness in dreams, and, you know, she woke up this morning remembering how you used to sing her to sleep. [chuckles softly]
[crying] Um, is that allowed, I mean, within your, [grateful], precious rules?

Well, um, dreams aren't wishes, they're just, [playful], gentle suggestions that hearts can choose to, [tender], follow or ignore, and, you know, your daughter's heart was already searching for a way home.
[peaceful] Then I suppose my real wish is to, [serene], remember how to sing that lullaby when she arrives.

[melodious] Now that, my dear, [magical], brave girl who became a remarkable woman, [loving], is a wish I can grant with, [joyful], all the magic I have left, and, um, you'll find the words have never really, you know, left your heart.
